forecast.review: Both forecasters add critical, concrete information I hadn’t incorporated: (1) a current record around 7–36 (~.16–.17), (2) a very large gap (~.11 WP) to the next-worst team, and (3) severe underlying metrics (run differential, ERA/WHIP/OPS) that support the record as signal, not noise. Forecaster 2’s argument is compelling on the magnitude of the gap and the predictive value of run differential, but 95% feels too high given three-plus weeks of variance, multiple potential basement teams, and the “checked on or after June 15” timing wrinkle. Forecaster 3’s framing (games remaining to that date, historical baselines, schedule difficulty) is solid and lands in a more conservative, but still high, range. Overall, their evidence strongly increases my estimate, but I would stay below the mid-90s due to short-window volatility and the resolution timing uncertainty.
forecast.rationale: Updating on the new data: If Colorado is ~.16–.17 WP with roughly a 0.11 gap to the second-worst team in mid-May, then over ~24–26 games before June 15 the chasing team would need to outperform the Rockies by about 6–8 wins to flip season-to-date WP. That’s possible but unlikely for any single team, and we need some team to not only slump but do so worse than the Rockies over this window. Colorado’s poor underlying performance (very negative run differential, bottom-tier pitching/hitting) and a tough upcoming schedule both support persistence at or near the bottom. Single-player returns (e.g., Tovar) don’t materially change near-term team quality. Countervailing considerations keep me shy of the 90s: (a) short-horizon variance can be large; (b) multiple bad teams exist, creating some chance one collapses harder; (c) resolution is based on when Metaculus checks on or after June 15, adding day-to-day volatility risk; and (d) small differences in games played can amplify volatility in WP. Net, the large current gap plus fundamentals make “Yes” more likely than not and substantially so, but not near-certain. I’m moving up significantly from my prior given the concrete gap and metrics.
